atoms.name: haumāmā
atoms.etymology: from the Greek word for the sun, Helios

atoms.name: pūtiwha
atoms.discovery_details: 30<sup>th</sup> of June, 1808 by Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Louis Jacques Thénard

atoms.name: waro
atoms.discovery_details: The Egyptians and Sumerians had diamonds before 3000 BC
atoms.etymology: from the Latin carbo, referring to coal & charcoal

atoms.name: hauota
atoms.etymology: from the French nitrogène, which means Potassium nitrate-producing

atoms.name: hāora
atoms.discovery_details: Unknown. Either a Polish alchemist in 1604 or in 1771 by Swedish pharmacist Carl Wilhelm Scheele

atoms.name: haukura
atoms.discovery_details: 1898 by British chemists Sir William Ramsay & Morris W. Travers

atoms.name: konutai
atoms.etymology: Unknown. Its symbol is derived from Natronium/Natrium

atoms.name: konumohe
atoms.etymology: Named after Aluminia (which is named after Alum)

atoms.name: Parārenga
atoms.discovery_details: 1669 by German Alchemist Hennig Brand. Properly discovered by Antoine Lavoisier in 1777
atoms.etymology: from the Ancient Greek name for Venus, translates as light-bearer

atoms.name: Sulfara
atoms.discovery_details: Before 2000 BC, China. Recognised as an element by Antoine Lavoisier in 1777

atoms.name: Āwera
atoms.discovery_details: 1894 by Lord Rayleigh and William Ramsay
atoms.etymology: Derived from the Greek word for lazy

atoms.name: Pōtāsiamu
atoms.etymology: from Pot-ash. Historically potassium-containing salts were produced by boiling ash. K is from Kali, from Alkali

atoms.name: Manahau
atoms.discovery_details: 1801 by Andrés Manuel del Río. Isolated in 1830 by Nils Gabriel Sefström
atoms.etymology: after the Norse goddess of beauty & fertility, Vanadís (Freyja)

atoms.name: Kōpera
atoms.discovery_details: Discovered 1794, isolated in 1797 by Louis Nicolas Vauquelin

atoms.name: Manganēse
atoms.etymology: after Magnesia in Greece (same as Magnesium)

atoms.name: Hakarangi
atoms.etymology: from proto-Germanic isarnon. Its chemical symbol comes from its Latin name ferrum

atoms.name: Horīmiona
atoms.etymology: from Kobald, a sprite in Germainc mythology

atoms.name: Nihōkio
atoms.etymology: from the sprite of Germanic mythology

atoms.name: Koperu
atoms.discovery_details: before 9000 BC in the Middle East
atoms.etymology: after Cyprus, a significant mining location to Ancient Rome

atoms.name: Mētiri
atoms.discovery_details: India before 1000 BC. Properly in 1746 by Andreas Sigismund Marggraf

atoms.name: Kaliama
atoms.etymology: after Gallia, the Roman province Gaul. Roughly the area of modern France

atoms.name: Seleni
atoms.discovery_details: 1817 by Jöns Jakob Berzelius & Johann Gottlieb Gahn
atoms.etymology: after Selene, the Greek moon goddess

atoms.name: Bruka
atoms.discovery_details: 1825 by Antoine Jérôme Balard (France) & Carl Jacob Löwig (Germany)

atoms.name: Kriptona
atoms.etymology: from Ancient Greek Kryptos, meaning the hidden one

atoms.name: Rubidiama
atoms.discovery_details: 1861 by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff. Isolated by George de Hevesy

atoms.name: Strautio
atoms.etymology: after stronantine, which gets its name from the Scottish village of Strontian

atoms.name: Kitiama
atoms.etymology: named after the Swedish village of Ytterby

atoms.name: Molybedeno
atoms.etymology: from the Neo-Latin equivalent of Ancient Greek molybdos, meaning lead

atoms.name: Tekahiko
atoms.discovery_details: 1937 by Emilio Segrè and Carlo Perrier
atoms.etymology: from Greek, meaning synthetic with the -ium suffix

atoms.name: Rūtene
atoms.etymology: after Ruthenia, the Latin name for the region controlled by the Kievan Rus

atoms.name: Rihōdiama
atoms.etymology: after the rose-colour of a compound it forms with Chlorine

atoms.name: Pallātina
atoms.etymology: after asteroid Pallas, which was named after Pallas Athena

atoms.name: Hakaremo
atoms.etymology: ultimately from proto-Germanic silubra. Its symbol comes from its name, argentum

atoms.name: Katī
atoms.discovery_details: 1817 by Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann and Friedrich Stromeyer

atoms.name: Tiniamu
atoms.discovery_details: 1863 by Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter
atoms.etymology: after the inidgo blue of its visible spectrum (ultimately derived from India)

atoms.name: Tini
atoms.etymology: from proto-Germanic tin-om. Its symbol is derived from its Latin name stannum

atoms.name: Antimoni
atoms.discovery_details: before 815 AD by Jabir ibn Hayyan
atoms.etymology: from its Byzantine Greek name, antimonium. The origin of this is unknown.

atoms.name: Xerona
atoms.discovery_details: 1898 by William Ramsay and Morris Travers

atoms.name: Ceziamo
atoms.discovery_details: 1860 by Robert Bunsen and Gustav Kirchhoff. Isolated in 1882 by Carl Setterberg
atoms.etymology: from Latin Caesius (bluish-grey), after its spectral colours.

atoms.name: Barāmo
atoms.discovery_details: 1772 by Carl Wilhelm Scheele. 1808 by Humphry Davy
atoms.etymology: from the Alchemical baryta which is derived from Greek Barys, meaning heavy

atoms.name: Lantana
atoms.etymology: from the Ancient Greek lanthanein, meaning to lie hidden

atoms.name: Serio
atoms.discovery_details: 1803 by M.H. Klaproth, J.J. Berzelius, Wilhelm Hisinger. Isolated 1838 by C.G. Mosander
atoms.etymology: after Ceres, the Roman god of agriculture

atoms.name: Prometeo
atoms.discovery_details: 1942 by Chien Shiung Wu, E. Segrè, H. Bethe. Isolated 1945 by C.D. Coryell, J.A. Marinsky, L.E. Glendenin

atoms.name: Samario
atoms.etymology: after samarskite (ultimately from Russian mining engineer Vassili Samarsky-Bykhovets)

atoms.name: Gadolīnio
atoms.discovery_details: 1880 by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac. Isolated 1886 by Lecoq de Boisbaudran
atoms.etymology: after Gadolinite (from Swedish/Finnish chemist Johan Gadolin)

atoms.name: Holimio
atoms.discovery_details: 1878 by Jacques-Louis Soret and Marc Delafontaine
atoms.etymology: after the Latin name for Stockholm, Sweden

atoms.name: Iterbio
atoms.discovery_details: 1878 by Jean Charles Galissard de Marignac. Isolated 1906 by Carl Auer von Welsbach

atoms.name: Lutecio
atoms.discovery_details: 1906 by Carl Auer von Welsbach and Georges Urbain. Isolated by Welsbach, 1906
atoms.etymology: after the Latin name for Paris (Lutetia)

atoms.name: Hafnio
atoms.discovery_details: 1922 by Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy
atoms.etymology: from the Latin name for Copenhagen, Hafnia

atoms.name: Taianio
atoms.discovery_details: 1802 by Anders Gustaf Ekeberg. Recognised as a distinct element in 1844 by Heinrich Rose

atoms.name: Tungarā
atoms.discovery_details: 1781 by Juan José Elhuyar and Fausto Elhuyar. Isolated two years later
atoms.etymology: from Swedish, meaning heavy stone. In German, it is called wolfram (Hence, W)

atoms.name: Iridio
atoms.etymology: after the Greek goddess Iris (rainbow personification) because of its colourful salts

atoms.name: Hōhua
atoms.etymology: from proto-Germanic gultha. Its symbol is from its Latin aurum

atoms.name: Whakāria
atoms.etymology: after the Roman god. Formerly called hydrargyrum (Greek, meaning water-silver), hence its symbol

atoms.name: Tatara
atoms.discovery_details: 1861 by William Crookes (Britain), it was isolated the following year.

atoms.name: Teana
atoms.etymology: No one knows. It has been called the same thing for centuries. Symbol derived from latin plumbum

atoms.name: Bismuta
atoms.etymology: Unknown. Probably from Arabic bi ismid, which means having the properties of antimony

atoms.name: Pōlōnio
atoms.discovery_details: 1898 by Pierre & Marie Curie. Isolated 1902 by Willy Marckwald
atoms.etymology: from Polonia, the Latin name for Poland

atoms.name: Astātina
atoms.discovery_details: 1940 by Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segrè

atoms.name: Radono
atoms.discovery_details: 1899 by E. Rutherford (New Zealand) and R.B. Owens (USA). Isolated 1910 by W. Ramsay & R. Whytlaw-Gray
atoms.etymology: Initially it was called radium emanation. In 1918 it was one of several shortened proposed names

atoms.name: Rāđio
atoms.discovery_details: 1898 by Pierre & Marie Curie. Isolated by Marie, 1910
atoms.etymology: from Latin radius. Meaning ray. Because of its emissions.

atoms.name: Terano
atoms.etymology: after Thor, the Norse god of thunder

atoms.name: Purotio
atoms.discovery_details: 1913 by Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helmuth Göhring

atoms.name: Urana
atoms.discovery_details: 1789 by Martin Heinrich Klaproth. Isolated 1841 by Eugène-Melchior Péligot
atoms.etymology: after Uranus (the planet). Ultimately derived from the Greek god of the sky

atoms.name: Neptunio
atoms.discovery_details: 1940 by Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson
atoms.etymology: after Neptune (the planet). Ultimately derived from the Greek god of the sea

atoms.name: Piura
atoms.discovery_details: 1940–1 by Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur Wahl, Joseph W. Kennedy, Edwin McMillan
atoms.etymology: after Pluto (the planet). Ultimately derived from the Greek god of the underworld

atoms.name: Amerikia
atoms.discovery_details: 1944 by Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso

atoms.name: Kūriama
atoms.discovery_details: 1944 by Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso

atoms.name: Makasiumi
atoms.etymology: after Dmitri Mendeleev, father of the Periodic Table

atoms.name: Nōbēliama
atoms.discovery_details: 1966 by the Joint Institute for Nuclear Research

atoms.name: Rutherfordiumu
atoms.discovery_details: 1964 in the Soviet Union. Confirmed 1969, USA.

atoms.name: Sēburio
atoms.etymology: after the American nuclear chemist Glenn T. Seaborg

atoms.name: Hāsiamu
atoms.etymology: after the German state of Hesse

atoms.name: Darmasutadio
atoms.etymology: after Darmstadt, Germany (location of its discovery)

atoms.name: Furasīamu
atoms.etymology: after the Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions (ultimately after Georgy Flyorov)

atoms.name: Livermorio
atoms.etymology: after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (ultimately after Livermore, California)

atoms.name: Tennessino
atoms.discovery_details: 2009 by JINR, LLNL, Vanderbilt University & Oak Ridge National Laboratory
